claim.text: conventional foundations must extend below the frost line — often 1.5 to 2 meters deep
claim.claim: Frost line depth requiring foundation excavation is often 1.5 to 2 meters in cold climates

results.summary: Frost line depths of 1.5 to 2 meters (approximately 5 to 6.5 feet) are accurate for cold climate regions.
results.detail: Building codes in cold climate regions require foundations to extend below the frost line to prevent frost heave. In northern U.S. states and Canada, frost line depths commonly range from 1.2m (4 feet) in moderately cold areas to over 2m (6+ feet) in very cold regions like Minnesota, Wisconsin, and northern Canada. The claim's range of 1.5 to 2 meters is well within documented requirements for cold climates.

claim.text: accepted by the Canadian building code
claim.claim: Frost-protected shallow foundations are accepted by the Canadian building code

results.summary: Frost-protected shallow foundations (FPSF) are accepted under the National Building Code of Canada as an alternative to conventional deep foundations.
results.detail: The National Building Code of Canada has provisions for frost-protected shallow foundations, which use insulation to protect foundations from frost heave rather than extending below the frost line. This approach has been recognized in Canadian building standards and is referenced in Part 9 of the NBC. FPSF designs are based on principles established in research from Scandinavian countries and have been adopted in North American codes including Canada.
sources: National Research Council Canada publications on foundation design

claim.text: Extend rigid insulation (EPS or XPS) horizontally at least 1.2 meters from the building perimeter
claim.claim: FPSF requires horizontal insulation extending at least 1.2 meters from building perimeter

results.summary: FPSF horizontal insulation requirements vary by climate zone and are not a fixed 1.2 meters for all applications.
results.detail: According to ASCE 32 (Design and Construction of Frost-Protected Shallow Foundations) and ICC building codes, horizontal wing insulation requirements for FPSF vary significantly based on the Air Freezing Index of the location. In colder climates (higher AFI), horizontal extensions can range from approximately 0.3 meters (12 inches) in milder frost areas to over 1.8 meters (72 inches) in severe cold climates. The 1.2 meter figure falls within the typical range but is not a universal minimum requirement. The actual requirement depends on climate zone, building heat loss characteristics, and whether the building is heated or unheated.
sources: ASCE 32-01 Design and Construction of Frost-Protected Shallow Foundations
ICC International Residential Code Chapter 4 - Foundations
